predictions: Zully Broussard's selfless kidney donation initiated a six-person transplant chain, facilitated by a new matching program.  This program, MatchGrid, rapidly connects donor-recipient pairs, maximizing the impact of altruistic donations and significantly reducing transplant wait times.

The MLS, launched in 1996, has significantly grown, boasting increased attendance, more teams, and a lucrative TV deal.  Despite initial struggles and challenges like a salary cap limiting competitiveness, the league is attracting top talent and aiming for greater prominence in US sports.

Swansea's Gomis collapsed during a match due to low blood pressure, a pre-existing condition.  While the incident was alarming, he's recovering well and the club was aware of his history.  The situation contrasts sharply with past fatal on-field collapses.

Frustrated by a bad shot, Rory McIlroy threw his 3-iron into a lake during the WGC Cadillac Championship.  Despite this, he finished with a 70, but remains eight shots behind leader JB Holmes.  McIlroy attributed his struggles to a disconnect between his practice and on-course performance.

Thirteen-year-old Cayman Naib disappeared in Pennsylvania.  Hundreds are searching, aided by technology and the Civil Air Patrol.  His parents believe he left impulsively after receiving a school email about overdue homework.  They've appealed to him to return home.

Curt Schilling tracked down and exposed Twitter users who sent rape threats to his daughter.  Their actions resulted in job losses and suspensions.  The incident highlights the need for online accountability and responsible parenting while emphasizing that free speech isn't without consequences.

Two American women were arrested in Rome for carving their initials into the Colosseum.  This follows similar incidents involving tourists defacing historical sites in Rome, Egypt, Cambodia, and Peru, highlighting a global problem of disrespectful tourist behavior.

Prince and 3rdEyeGirl's Hit & Run Tour hits the US for the first time in Louisville, KY on March 14th.  Ticket sales begin March 9th, with proceeds benefiting Louisville charities.  The venue remains unannounced.

A shooting at a Bamako bar killed five (including French and Belgian citizens) and wounded eight.  Al-Murabitun, a North African jihadist group, claimed responsibility, citing retaliation for a leader's death.  The attack fueled condemnation and strengthened resolve against terrorism.

Jonny Evans and Papiss Cisse face six-game bans for allegedly spitting at each other during a Premier League match.  The FA charged them based on video evidence, despite the referee missing the incident.  Both players deny intentional spitting, but commentators condemned the actions.

The March 10, 2015, CNN Student News covered a solar-powered plane's global circumnavigation attempt, Siberian craters, and a unique Everest view.  The show also included a transcript and a "Roll Call" segment for student participation.

ISIS-affiliated militants attacked a Libyan oil field, kidnapping nine foreign workers (including four Filipinos, an Austrian, a Czech, and a Ghanaian).  The attack highlights Libya's deteriorating security situation and ongoing violence targeting oil fields.

Wichita North High School students surprised their principal, Sherman Padgett, with a "senior prank" involving a bucket for collecting notes of gratitude and appreciation for his dedication and support.  Padgett was deeply moved by the heartfelt messages.

Norman Lee, a DC and Marvel comic book artist, is presumed dead after a snorkeling accident in Grand Cayman.  Strong currents hampered the search, now a recovery mission, leaving friends and colleagues mourning his loss.

The March 9, 2015, CNN Student News covered the anniversary of Selma's Edmund Pettus Bridge march, the missing Malaysia Airlines flight, and International Women's Day,  analyzed the US unemployment report, and offered a "Roll Call" segment for schools.  A transcript was available.

Jessie Usher joins Liam Hemsworth and Jeff Goldblum in the "Independence Day" sequel, playing Will Smith's son.  The film, directed by Roland Emmerich, is slated for release June 24, 2016.  Usher stars in Starz's "Survivor's Remorse."
87-year-old former Vice President Walter Mondale was released from the Mayo Clinic after treatment for influenza.  He was admitted following a fever during a routine checkup.  He's recovering well.

Kyle Waring's ShipSnowYo.com sells Boston snow ($89 for 6 lbs) to customers outside New England.  His business, born from a snow-shoveling joke, has filled over 133 orders, capitalizing on Boston's record snowfall.  He plans to expand to other seasonal items.

Syrian, Iraqi, and Palestinian refugee women in Jordan, despite facing poverty, legal barriers, and violence, are building businesses and supporting their families.  Aid agencies must shift from short-term assistance to empowering women with skills, resources, and protection to achieve long-term economic independence.

Real Madrid lost 1-0 to Athletic Bilbao, potentially giving Barcelona the La Liga lead.  Real's lack of offensive efficiency concerns Ancelotti.  Bayern Munich won in the Bundesliga, while PSG leads Ligue 1 temporarily.

Japanese police arrested a 40-year-old man who confessed to stabbing five elderly neighbors to death in Sumoto city.  The victims, two couples and one woman, lived near the suspect, who shared their surname.
A suicide car bombing near a Lashkar Gah police vehicle killed seven and injured 23, mostly civilians including children.  The attacker's identity and motive remain unknown.

Pakistan's Supreme Court ordered the release of Zaki-ur-Rehman Lakhvi, the alleged mastermind of the 2008 Mumbai attacks, deeming his detention illegal.  India strongly condemned the decision, summoning Pakistan's high commissioner.

A DeKalb County police officer shot and killed an unarmed, naked African-American man who charged at him.  The incident is under investigation by the Georgia Bureau of Investigations, prompting discussion about police training for mental health crises.

A photo of a weasel riding a woodpecker went viral.  Taken in an Essex park, the image shows a least weasel attempting (unsuccessfully) to prey on a green woodpecker.  Experts say while unusual, a hungry weasel might attack, though likely couldn't kill the bird.  The photo spawned numerous humorous online parodies.

eBay is flooded with listings selling air allegedly from Kanye West concerts, reaching exorbitant prices despite lacking authenticity.  This follows the release of his Adidas Yeezy Boost sneakers, priced far higher than West intended.  Similar novelty items are also appearing.

Delta Flight 1086 skidded off LaGuardia's runway due to suspected brake failure despite "max" auto-brake setting.  The crew reported no deceleration, and the plane sustained significant damage, injuring 23 passengers.  The NTSB is investigating.

Over 100 Pakistani schools were renamed after the 132 children killed in a Taliban attack on the Army Public School in Peshawar last December, as a tribute to their bravery.  A suspect was arrested in February.
The Salvation Army in South Africa uses the "the dress" viral image, modified to show a bruised model, to raise awareness about domestic violence, highlighting the difficulty in recognizing abuse.

NASCAR reinstated Kurt Busch, who was suspended for alleged domestic violence, after he completed a behavioral program and the charges were dropped.  He remains on indefinite probation and must continue treatment.

The MH370 interim report reveals significant delays and communication failures in the initial response to the plane's disappearance.  These lapses, including delayed distress signals and unshared radar data, hampered the search and highlight crucial shortcomings in international aviation protocols.
A ferry capsized in Myanmar due to bad weather, killing 21 and leaving 21 missing.  167 were rescued.  This follows a string of fatal ferry accidents in the region, highlighting safety concerns.

Myanmar warplanes bombed a Chinese sugarcane field, killing four and injuring nine.  China responded by sending fighter jets to patrol the border, summoning Myanmar's ambassador, and demanding an investigation and accountability for the cross-border attack.

Self-diagnosing online can be misleading.  Unreliable sources, emotional biases, and neglecting professional medical advice are common pitfalls.  Use reputable websites, share online research with doctors, and seek professional help when necessary, rather than delaying treatment.

A Nevada grand jury indicted 19-year-old Erich Nowsch Jr. for murder, attempted murder, and weapons charges in the shooting death of his neighbor, Tammy Meyers.  Nowsch claims self-defense, while police allege a road-rage incident escalated to gunfire.  The driver of the other car remains at large.

Recent racial tensions, highlighted by police shootings and racist incidents, demand improved police-community relations.  Solutions include community policing (foot patrols, bike units),  mediation, and fostering positive interactions to build trust and mutual respect, replacing fear and mistrust.

A North Korean diplomat in Bangladesh was caught smuggling $1 million worth of undeclared gold.  Bangladesh protested, and the diplomat, who apologized, has left the country.  The incident's significance remains unclear.

A Utah toddler, Lily, survived a car crash that killed her mother.  Rescuers found her upside down in the submerged car 14 hours later.  Her father says she's recovering well, and he's incredibly grateful.

Two helicopter crashes occurred this week: an EagleMed helicopter crashed in Oklahoma, with three aboard; and an Army Black Hawk crashed in Florida, killing all 11 service members.  Investigations are underway.

Monohm's Runcible, a circular "anti-smartphone," challenges the rectangular dominance of screens.  Its circular form aims to reduce distractions and promote mindful interaction, prompting a reconsideration of how device shape influences user experience.

The upcoming Star Wars novel, "Lords of the Sith," introduces Moff Mors, the franchise's first officially canon gay character—a lesbian Imperial official.  This marks a significant step for LGBTQ+ representation in the Star Wars universe.

Suicide bombers attacked a Lahore church, killing at least 14 and wounding 78.  The Pakistani Taliban claimed responsibility, vowing further attacks until Sharia law is implemented.  The attack highlights ongoing persecution of religious minorities in Pakistan.

A massive IRS impersonation scam has defrauded over 3,000 victims of more than $15 million since 2013.  Scammers, likely based in India, use stolen information to convincingly threaten victims with lawsuits or arrest unless they pay.  Authorities urge anyone receiving such calls to hang up immediately.

Republican efforts to undermine Obama's Iran policy, while seemingly extraordinary, pale in comparison to past partisan actions by both Democrats and Republicans, demonstrating that foreign policy has always been a highly politicized arena, challenging executive authority.

Pope Francis, in a recent interview, expects a short papacy (4-5 years),  comparing it to a gambler's mindset.  He enjoys his role but misses anonymity and plans a "Jubilee of Mercy."  He also stated that spanking children is acceptable if not demeaning.

Ashton Kutcher's Facebook post highlighting the lack of baby changing tables in men's restrooms sparked a debate about parental equality.  Many parents supported his point, emphasizing the need for better facilities for dads and same-sex parents.  The post generated significant online discussion.

Spain's "world's most dangerous path," Caminito del Rey, reopens March 26 after a €5.5 million reconstruction.  The renovated cliffside walkway, closed since 2000 due to fatal accidents, offers stunning views and will be free for six months.  Reservations are required.

Isaac Herzog, leading in pre-election polls, aims to become Israel's next Prime Minister.  He emphasizes social justice, collaboration with world powers against a nuclear Iran, and restarting peace talks with Palestinians, leveraging his family's political legacy.

Hundreds of thousands of Brazilians protested President Rousseff's alleged inaction regarding a massive Petrobras corruption scandal, amid a struggling economy.  While Rousseff hasn't been implicated, protesters demand her impeachment, fueled by public perception of her accountability.  Further protests are planned.

Sixteen Indonesian citizens, including children, were detained in Turkey for planning to enter Syria.  A separate group of sixteen Indonesians also went missing in Turkey, possibly entering Syria. Indonesia is investigating both incidents.

Crude bombs were thrown at a Tamil news station in India after it planned a show on the mangalsutra necklace, prompting outrage from Hindu groups.  This incident highlights India's ongoing struggle with free speech, facing censorship through legal means and violent protests.

Serena Williams returns to Indian Wells after a 14-year boycott stemming from 2001 racial abuse and accusations of match-fixing involving her and her sister Venus.  Despite lingering family resentment, Serena seeks closure, hoping for a warm reception.

A new mobile app by Kick It Out has increased reporting of racist and other abusive behavior in English football by 35%, leading to more investigations and sanctions.  Video evidence, like the Paris metro incident, is proving particularly effective in identifying offenders.

Lisa Green argues parents should proactively seek legal counsel for their teens,  emphasizing the swift transition from everyday life to serious legal trouble.  She advises parents to understand teen legal rights, school policies, and social host laws, advocating for informed parenting, not shielding teens from consequences.

Photographer Ignacio Evangelista documents abandoned European border checkpoints, remnants of the pre-Schengen era.  His "After Schengen" project showcases the ghostly architecture of these former control points, highlighting the transformation of European travel and the lingering atmosphere of past border controls.

Daniel Ricciardo, despite a past disqualification due to a fuel flow violation, is eager for the Australian Grand Prix.  He acknowledges F1's reliance on technology and the potential for mechanical failures, but aims for redemption after last year's disappointment.

Disney's live-action "Cinderella" debuted strongly, exceeding expectations with $70.1 million, outperforming "Maleficent."  "Run All Night," starring Liam Neeson, underperformed.  "It Follows" excelled in limited release, while "Kingsman: The Secret Service" continued its success.

Harper Lee's upcoming book, "Go Set a Watchman," faces questions about her consent at age 88.  An Alabama investigation concluded she understood and wanted publication, closing the case.  The book, written before "To Kill a Mockingbird," is still scheduled for July release.

A photo of a sailor cradling his baby in an American flag sparked debate.  Some viewed it as patriotic, representing service and family, while others deemed it disrespectful, citing the flag code.  The photographer, a Navy veteran, defended the image, and many online supported her.

Candida Moss answers viewer questions about CNN's "Finding Jesus,"  explaining the significance of the number 40 in the Bible, the relationship between Jesus and John the Baptist's followers, DNA evidence related to Jesus's remains, and extra-biblical sources confirming John the Baptist's existence.

Smartwatches offer convenience, but also create a "phantom device effect," leading to compulsive checking and anxiety.  They track vast personal data, potentially fueling self-obsession and neglecting real-world interactions, creating an "internet of me."

Robert Durst, charged with the 2000 murder of Susan Berman, had his Houston home raided after his New Orleans arrest.  His lawyer claims the actions are a result of the HBO documentary "The Jinx," and doubts evidence will be found.  Durst awaits extradition to Los Angeles.

The Southern Poverty Law Center reports a 17% decrease in US hate groups since 2013, reaching their lowest levels since 2005.  This decline, attributed to various factors including economic recovery and online activity, is most pronounced in the Ku Klux Klan.  However, concerns remain about lone-wolf extremists and rising Islamophobia.

Reverend Fred Craddock, a renowned preacher known for his unique, conversational style, died at 86.  His impactful sermons,  combined with his compassionate life,  left an enduring legacy on preaching and service.

The State Department only recently began automatically archiving high-level officials' emails, raising questions about Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server.  Republicans demand access to Clinton's server, while Clinton claims she emailed government officials to ensure preservation.  The State Department acknowledges past record-keeping imperfections.

Ten American aid workers, exposed to Ebola in Sierra Leone, returned to the US for monitoring.  One developed symptoms and was hospitalized; others remain asymptomatic.  The infected colleague in critical condition is receiving treatment at NIH.

Arsenal defeated Manchester United 2-1 in the FA Cup quarterfinals at Old Trafford.  Welbeck scored the winner against his former club, while Di Maria was sent off for grabbing the referee.  Arsenal advances to the semifinals.

The Justice Department found Ferguson, Missouri, engaged in a pattern of racially discriminatory practices, using fines and fees to generate revenue rather than prioritize public safety.  This impacted residents like Loistine Hoskin, who lost her car and paid excessive fines.  The city is implementing reforms.

Amidst health speculation following canceled appearances, Putin's Kremlin released photos showing him meeting with the Supreme Court head.  His spokesperson dismissed rumors as "spring fever," assuring Putin's robust health.  Upcoming meetings are scheduled.

Despite Ibrahimovic's red card and Silva's handball penalty conceded, PSG beat Chelsea in the Champions League Round of 16 on away goals, with Silva scoring the winning goal.  Bayern Munich also advanced, crushing Shakhtar Donetsk 7-0.

Five Chelsea fans were summoned to court for a racist attack on a black man on the Paris Metro before a Champions League match.  The incident, caught on video, showed the fans preventing the man from boarding and chanting racist slurs.  Chelsea condemned the actions, and the fans face potential life bans and football banning orders.

Sotheby's is auctioning Maurizio Cattelan's black granite sculpture detailing every England football team defeat from 1874-1998 for $900,000.  The satirical artwork,  commenting on pride and missed opportunities, is on display until March 10th.

Tens of thousands rallied in Tel Aviv, demanding a change in Israeli leadership due to dissatisfaction with Prime Minister Netanyahu's handling of a two-state solution and the cost of living.  While Netanyahu retains support, the rally mirrors 2011 protests expressing widespread discontent.

The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame's 30th annual induction ceremony will feature performances by Beck and John Legend, and inductions by Paul McCartney, Patti Smith, and others.  The ceremony, airing May 30th on HBO, will honor seven artists.

A US Air Force veteran, Tairod Pugh, pleaded not guilty to charges of attempting to support ISIS.  Turkish authorities stopped him from entering Syria in January.  Evidence included a letter expressing his intent to join ISIS and jihadist propaganda on his devices.

Silicon Valley's tech boom isn't creating good jobs, instead replacing them with low-wage or unstable "gig" work, harming millennials and threatening a widening wealth gap.  Holding Silicon Valley accountable is crucial to prevent a dystopian future.

The wreck of the CSS Georgia is being salvaged to deepen Savannah's shipping channel.  Initial artifacts include leg irons, cannons, and personal items, offering glimpses into shipboard life and the vessel's ultimately scuttled fate.  Larger components will be recovered later.

New Zealanders are seizing keys from foreign drivers due to dangerous driving, causing eight deaths recently.  Authorities condemn this vigilante justice, citing legal gray areas and advocating for improved driver education and road signage instead.  While foreign drivers are involved in a disproportionate number of accidents in some areas, it's not solely due to driving on the wrong side of the road.

Tropical Cyclone Pam, a powerful Category 4 storm, devastated Vanuatu, causing widespread destruction and leaving many homeless.  Relief efforts are urgently needed for food, water, and shelter.  The storm weakened after landfall but still poses threats to nearby islands and New Zealand.

Despite Iran's hostility towards Israel, Esfahan's Jewish community openly practices its faith, integrated into the city's fabric.  They identify as Iranian Jews, separate from Israeli politics, and coexist peacefully with their Muslim neighbors, though some overseas relatives express concern.

Israel's upcoming election focuses on domestic issues, ignoring the central issue of the Palestinian occupation.  Both Netanyahu and Herzog, despite differing rhetoric, show no intention of ending it, rendering the election largely inconsequential regarding Palestinian rights.

A Turkish TV network released a video purportedly showing three British schoolgirls near the Turkey-Syria border, believed to have joined ISIS.  The video's authenticity is unconfirmed, but it follows reports of a foreign "spy" assisting their travel to Syria.

Kerry Washington will star in and executive produce HBO's "Confirmation," a TV movie about the 1991 Clarence Thomas-Anita Hill Supreme Court hearings.  Susannah Grant will write, and Rick Famuyiwa may direct.  The film is a significant acquisition for HBO.

Forty-seven Republican senators sent a letter to Iran potentially undermining Obama's nuclear negotiations,  exemplifying a pattern of  disrespect towards the president, fueled by both explicit and implicit racial bias, exceeding typical political disagreements.

A CNN journalist interviewed Prince Charles at Birkhall, his Scottish home,  about his marriage to Camilla.  Camilla declined an interview but allowed filming during public appearances. The piece offers a glimpse into their relationship and life at Birkhall before Charles' ascension.

A UVA student's bloody arrest by alcohol control agents sparked protests and a campus forum with police.  The incident, under investigation, involved allegations of police brutality, prompting calls for justice and raising concerns about racial bias in policing.

Kelly Gissendaner, on death row, underwent profound spiritual transformation through theological studies.  Despite facing execution, her faith, remorse, and ministry to others exemplify redemption and hope, prompting calls for clemency.

Watertown police officers recounted an eight-minute shootout with the Boston Marathon bombing suspects, Tamerlan (killed) and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev.  Dzhokhar ran over his wounded brother, then escaped but was later apprehended.  The trial showcased the shootout and the boat where Dzhokhar hid.

An Army Black Hawk helicopter crashed in Florida, killing all 11 service members aboard.  The recovery operation is underway, focusing on retrieving the wreckage and the bodies.  The cause of the crash during a training exercise in heavy fog is under investigation.

A terrorist attack at Tunisia's Bardo Museum killed 23, mostly foreign tourists.  Two gunmen, identified by authorities, were killed.  Investigations are ongoing, with nine arrests made, and ISIS claimed responsibility.  The attack highlighted the instability in the region and the threat of radicalized individuals.

Following a DOJ report exposing systemic racism, Ferguson residents are attempting to recall Mayor Knowles for failing to control the police department.  This comes after the police chief and city manager resigned, and amidst ongoing investigations into officer shootings.

Ozgecan Aslan's murder sparked widespread protests in Turkey, highlighting the country's high rates of violence against women.  Her father plans to use donations to create a rehabilitation center for male abusers, focusing on love and change rather than revenge.  The case mirrors similar tragedies in India, underscoring a global issue of women's rights.

Lindsey Vonn won her record-breaking 65th World Cup victory in super-G, boosting her chances for end-of-season titles despite trailing in the overall standings.  Kjetil Jansrud secured the men's Super-G title.  The season concludes with intense competition for various titles.

The article highlights the pervasive issue of child sex trafficking in the US, citing harrowing examples.  It advocates for two bills: the JVTA, which supports victims and strengthens law enforcement, and the SETT, which encourages states to treat child victims as such, not criminals.

Following a deadly attack on a Tunisian museum, a social media campaign, "#IWillComeToTunisia," aims to bolster the nation's tourism industry, vital to its economy.  People worldwide are pledging visits to show solidarity and counter travel warnings.

Former Wimbledon champion Marion Bartoli is considering a comeback to professional tennis after retiring due to injury in 2013.  Her decision is prompting debate, with some advising full commitment.  Several other female stars have successfully returned after retirement.

Liza Minnelli, 68, has entered rehab for substance abuse, according to her spokesman.  This follows past struggles with alcohol and painkillers.  She's reportedly making good progress at an undisclosed facility.

Zaur Dadayev, the main suspect in Boris Nemtsov's murder, recanted his confession, claiming coercion.  Two human rights activists who interviewed him face charges, prompting Amnesty International's condemnation.  Other suspects also deny involvement, despite conflicting reports on alleged torture.

Ferguson, Missouri, seeks a new police chief to rebuild community trust shattered after the Michael Brown shooting.  The ideal candidate will need empathy, confidence, and a commitment to reforming the department's culture, mirroring Sanford, Florida's successful approach after the Trayvon Martin case.  Race is a factor, but finding the best candidate is paramount.

March Madness, the NCAA Tournament, is a highly-watched college basketball event showcasing both powerhouse and smaller programs.  It's a crucial platform for aspiring NBA players, with scouts assessing talent under intense pressure.  Smaller schools like Butler and Valparaiso have proven that success in March Madness can lead to significant exposure and professional opportunities.

Google CFO Patrick Pichette's resignation, lauded for prioritizing family, highlights the unattainable "work-life balance" ideal.  His privileged position allows early retirement; most lack this luxury, exposing the systemic issues in corporate culture hindering true balance.

A.J. Pero, Twisted Sister's longtime drummer, died at 55 from an apparent heart attack.  His bandmates are devastated by the loss of their brother and friend, who was also drumming for Adrenaline Mob at the time of his death.

Mexican lucha libre star Hijo del Perro Aguayo died after a wrestling match injury.  A flying kick from Rey Mysterio led to his collapse;  an investigation into possible manslaughter is underway.  His death caused widespread grief in the wrestling community.

An anonymous blackmailer threatened to poison New Zealand infant formula with 1080 poison unless the government ceased its pest control program.  Police launched an investigation, assuring the public that formula remains safe, while the government called the threat "eco-terrorism."

The University of Oklahoma expelled Sigma Alpha Epsilon after a video surfaced showing members singing a racist chant.  This follows a history of SAE controversies, including hazing, alcohol abuse, and sexual misconduct allegations at multiple universities, leading to numerous suspensions and chapter closures.

DC Comics revamped Superman and Wonder Woman's looks, giving them more casual and armored styles respectively.  Archie Andrews also received a modern makeover to coincide with his upcoming TV show.  These significant redesigns mark a major shift in comic book character appearances.

Pre-election polls incorrectly predicted a tight race between Netanyahu and Herzog.  Netanyahu won decisively, likely due to methodological flaws in polling, strategic voting, and his late shift to the right, consolidating right-wing votes.  This mirrors his 1996 surprise victory.

HBO's upcoming documentary, "Montage of Heck," offers an intimate look at Kurt Cobain's life, featuring unseen footage, interviews with loved ones, and an unreleased 12-minute acoustic track.  It premieres May 4th.

US Secretary of State John Kerry says progress has been made in Iran nuclear talks, but significant gaps remain before the March 24 deadline.  A deal is crucial to prevent Iran from obtaining nuclear weapons, but the focus is on achieving the right agreement, not rushing.

Eleven service members, seven Marines and four Louisiana National Guardsmen, died in a Black Hawk helicopter crash.  They were highly decorated veterans with extensive deployments and service, leaving behind families and loved ones.  One recently received the Silver Star.

The White House's classification of the Iran nuclear deal as a non-binding agreement, rather than a treaty requiring Senate approval, sparks a partisan clash. Republicans argue it's a treaty and accuse the administration of overreach, while the administration defends its actions, citing precedent and the deal's vulnerability without Senate approval.

Jeremy Clarkson, Top Gear's host, was suspended by the BBC for allegedly assaulting a producer.  This sparked a divided public response, with petitions both supporting and opposing him.  The incident follows previous controversies involving racism and a diplomatic incident in Argentina.  Top Gear's broadcast is suspended pending investigation.

Dolce & Gabbana's Milan fashion show celebrated mothers, showcasing feminine dresses and skirts with rose, lace, and child-like embroidery.  Models even carried children down the runway, creating a heartwarming familial atmosphere.

ISIS released a video showing a 19-year-old Israeli Arab man, Mohamed Musallam, being executed by a child.  Israel denies Musallam was a spy; his family says ISIS coerced him, recruiting him with false promises.  The video is another example of ISIS using children in propaganda.

Ferguson's turmoil, stemming from a police shooting and a damning report on racial bias, highlights a national problem: militarized, predominantly white police forces in majority-black communities.  Urgent reforms are needed, including diversifying police departments, curbing military equipment use, and implementing community policing models.

Two Chinese men received prison sentences for selling military intelligence, including photos of the Liaoning aircraft carrier, to foreign agents posing as journalists and editors.  One man photographed military bases, the other the aircraft carrier.

Melissa Benoist stars as Supergirl in a new CBS series.  The costume, designed by Colleen Atwood, reflects a modern action hero.  The show features a cast including Calista Flockhart and familiar DC characters, and is executive produced by Greg Berlanti.

The article criticizes both Republican senators who sent a letter to Iran undermining nuclear negotiations and Hillary Clinton's handling of her emails.  Both actions, while stemming from legitimate concerns, deepened political polarization and hindered progress, demonstrating "wooden-headedness" and a failure to learn from past mistakes.

A 12-year-old boy, born with a limb difference, receives a 3D-printed electronic robotic arm from UCF students.  The arm, customized to his preferences, empowers him and inspires him to help other children.

The author contrasts their upbringing with their current same-sex relationship, highlighting the persistent gendered division of household labor.  While their same-sex partnership offers a more equitable distribution, systemic issues remain, requiring men to actively challenge traditional roles and value domestic work.

Larry David's Broadway debut, "Fish in the Dark," is a box office success but faces criticism for stereotypical portrayal of its Hispanic maid.  Conversely, the National Asian Artists Project cancelled its all-Asian "Show Boat" production due to concerns over cultural appropriation and insensitivity.  The incidents highlight complex issues of representation and casting in contemporary theater.

Ben Stiller and Owen Wilson, reprising their "Zoolander" roles, surprised Paris Fashion Week attendees at the Valentino show, promoting the upcoming "Zoolander 2" film.  Their runway appearance was a successful publicity stunt.

Following a racist video by University of Oklahoma's Sigma Alpha Epsilon fraternity, the university expelled two students, disaffiliated with the fraternity, and announced a new vice president for diversity—a position planned before the incident.  The fraternity's national chapter is also investigating.

Jeremy Clarkson, despite accusations of abuse and racism, maintains immense popularity.  His controversies, seemingly calculated, boost his profile and garner fervent fan support, who view criticism as overreactions.  His behavior is likened to a religious ritual, where suffering at the hands of a celebrity is seen as a blessing.

University President Boren swiftly condemned a racist fraternity video, expelling students and severing ties with the fraternity.  His decisive action, while sparking legal debate, shifted social norms.  Long-term, he should address systemic racism within the university and encourage broader community dialogue on racial inequity.

A Palestinian man rammed his car into Israeli border police and a cyclist in Jerusalem, injuring them.  Police shot and arrested the attacker, whom Hamas praised.  The incident is considered a terror attack, escalating regional tensions.

The National Gallery in London has banned selfie sticks, joining other museums worldwide.  The ban, supported by #MuseumSelfie Day's creator, aims to prevent disruptions to visitors and artwork caused by the devices.  Selfies are allowed, just not with selfie sticks.

Republicans' control of Congress has resulted in a manufactured political crisis, threatening the Department of Homeland Security and jeopardizing national security.  This dysfunctional behavior, prioritizing political gain over effective governance, is alienating voters.

Pop star Cody Simpson is promoting the UN's International Day of Happiness by performing at SXSW and contributing to a #HappySoundsLike playlist featuring songs chosen by celebrities.  He emphasizes music's power to bring happiness and advocates for genuine, meaningful music.

At the Gridiron Club dinner, President Obama joked about legalized marijuana in D.C., Hillary Clinton's email server, and birtherism.  Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker also attended, addressing Giuliani's comments about Obama's patriotism.  The event, known for its off-the-record nature, allowed for relaxed humor.

A 1,000-year-old mummified monk statue, stolen from a Chinese temple in 1995, was discovered in the Netherlands.  Chinese authorities are investigating its provenance and seeking repatriation from a private collector, after its display in Hungary was halted.

Penn State's Kappa Delta Rho fraternity was suspended after allegedly posting compromising photos of women on a private Facebook page.  Police and university officials are investigating, and the university is considering reevaluating its fraternity system.  The incident raises concerns about campus safety and handling of sex crime reports.

The March 25, 2015, CNN Student News covered Afghanistan troop levels, Israeli denials of spying on Iran talks, a French Alps plane crash, and a CNN Hero profile.  The page also offered a transcript and a "Roll Call" for school mentions.

Parisa Tabriz, Google's "Security Princess,"  works to identify and fix vulnerabilities in Chrome before malicious hackers do.  Her role involves understanding attacker psychology and combating cybercrime, including state-sponsored attacks.  She advocates for more women in tech and uses unconventional training methods.

A group claiming to be the Islamic State Hacking Division released online the names and addresses of roughly 100 U.S. troops, urging attacks.  Authorities are investigating the threat's credibility, contacting the affected personnel, and advising troops to limit online personal information.

Serena Williams returned to Indian Wells after a 14-year boycott due to racial abuse she and her family faced in 2001.  Overcome with emotion, she received a warm welcome, viewing her return as a victory for equality, surpassing any trophy.

Chuck Norris' 75th birthday is celebrated with humorous anecdotes highlighting his legendary toughness.  Jokes depict him as unbeatable, even defying time itself.  The article confirms his actual birthdate as March 10, 1940.

Serena Williams returns to the Indian Wells tournament after a 14-year boycott stemming from racist abuse and fan suspicion of a rigged match with her sister.  She sought her parents' support before deciding to return, emphasizing forgiveness and strength.

Pi Day (March 14th) is extra special in 2015, aligning with 3.1415.  Celebrations, originating at the Exploratorium 27 years ago, include pie-eating contests, parades, and Einstein-themed events, marking both Pi Day and Einstein's birthday.

Richard III's remains, discovered under a Leicester car park, revealed details about his life:  fair hair, blue eyes, a rich diet (including heron!), a roundworm infection, and battle wounds consistent with his death at Bosworth Field.  His scoliosis was less severe than depicted.

Tom Hanks, a friend of Carly Rae Jepsen's manager, stars in her "I Really Like You" music video, lip-syncing and participating in a flash mob.  His appearance, suggested by Hanks himself, is a surprisingly delightful addition.

A judge ordered the release of photos depicting alleged detainee abuse in Iraq and Afghanistan, rejecting the Defense Department's claim that their release would endanger U.S. personnel.  The government has 60 days to appeal.

David Crosby accidentally hit a jogger in California while driving, causing multiple fractures.  The jogger's injuries are not life-threatening.  Crosby cooperated with authorities and was not impaired; the sun obscured his view of the jogger.

Coalition airstrikes, at Iraq's request, support Iraqi forces battling ISIS in Tikrit.  The goal is to weaken ISIS strongholds, enabling Iraqi forces to retake the city, a key step towards potentially recapturing Mosul.

Denise Huskins, reported kidnapped from her Bay Area home, was found safe in Huntington Beach.  Police are investigating, considering all possibilities, including whether a ransom was paid.  The FBI is involved.

Former NFL player Darren Sharper pleaded guilty to sexual assault and attempted sexual assault in Arizona, receiving a nine-year prison sentence without parole eligibility.  This follows similar charges in other states.

Germanwings Flight 9525 experienced a rapid, controlled descent before crashing in the Alps.  The recovered black box and flight data indicate a potentially deliberate action by the pilot, though the cause remains unknown pending investigation.  No distress call was issued.

The NIH will admit a second Ebola patient, an American healthcare worker from Sierra Leone, to its Maryland hospital Friday.  This follows the successful treatment of another Ebola patient there last year.  The current Ebola outbreak has killed over 10,000 people.

The VA is restricting veterans' access to community care under the Choice Act, despite congressional intent.  A new bill, S. 207, aims to force the VA to utilize its authority to provide veterans with the promised care.

Angelina Jolie underwent preventative surgery to remove her ovaries and fallopian tubes due to a BRCA1 gene mutation,  a decision driven by family history and blood test results.  While facing forced menopause, she feels empowered by her choice to minimize cancer risk.

BBC suspended Jeremy Clarkson from "Top Gear" following a physical altercation with a producer.  This follows previous controversies including racist remarks and a diplomatic incident in Argentina.  A petition for his reinstatement has gained significant support.

The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, facing lawsuits alleging insufficient action against scoutmaster sexual abuse, defends its preventative measures.  A key case highlights a scoutmaster's reinstatement despite prior misconduct, prompting debate over responsibility between the church and the Boy Scouts of America.

J.K. Rowling responded to a fan questioning Dumbledore's gay portrayal by stating that gay people simply look like people.  Her reply, made years after revealing Dumbledore's sexuality, was well-received by fans.

The reported kidnapping of Denise Huskins was a hoax.  Found unharmed, she and her boyfriend refused to cooperate with police, leading to frustration and a wasted investigation involving numerous agencies.  Charges are possible.

Rohana Rozhan, CEO of Astro Malaysia, a $4.6 billion media company, overcame a challenging upbringing to achieve success.  Known for her independence, she leads a company producing thousands of hours of content annually and champions women's advancement within the organization.

Jon Hamm, the "Mad Men" star, recently completed a 30-day rehab stint for alcohol abuse.  His representatives confirmed the news, requesting privacy.  This comes shortly before the final season of "Mad Men" premieres.

Creflo Dollar, a prosperity preacher, seeks $60 million from his congregation and supporters to buy a $65 million Gulfstream G650 private jet, citing safety concerns with his older plane.  The jet will facilitate global gospel spreading, according to his ministry.

A new study suggests Neanderthals were more sophisticated than previously thought.  Analysis of 130,000-year-old eagle talons found in Croatia reveals Neanderthals created jewelry, demonstrating advanced cognitive abilities and hunting skills.

Two University of Oklahoma students, Parker Rice and Levi Pettit, were expelled for participating in a racist fraternity video containing racial slurs and a lynching reference.  Both apologized, but their actions sparked widespread condemnation and protests.

An 11-year-old wore a Christian Grey costume to World Book Day, prompting his school to deem it inappropriate.  His mother defended the choice, highlighting a teacher's Dexter costume as a contrasting example. The school claims the costume was modified, allowing full participation.
A Washington driver used a cardboard cutout of the Dos Equis "Most Interesting Man" to illegally use the HOV lane.  A trooper issued a $124 ticket, praising the driver's creativity.

Severe storms, including at least seven tornadoes, ravaged Oklahoma, killing one and injuring dozens.  A mobile home park and gymnastics studio were heavily damaged near Tulsa.  Governor Fallin declared a state of emergency for 25 counties.  The unusual March storms resulted from a clash of warm and cold air masses.

Republicans, controlling Congress, aim to reverse Obama-era defense cuts, citing growing global threats and insufficient military readiness.  They propose restoring defense spending to pre-sequestration levels, arguing that underfunding jeopardizes national security and undermines military capabilities.

A massive winter storm, spanning 2,000 miles from New Mexico to New England, impacts 94 million people.  Heavy snow and ice cause widespread travel disruptions, school closures, and flooding.  While some enjoy the snow, many areas face significant challenges from the severe weather.

Detroit police discovered the bodies of a teenage girl and an 11-year-old boy in a freezer during an eviction.  Their mother was arrested on child abuse charges, and two older siblings are in protective custody.  The cause of death is under investigation.

Putin's 10-day absence fueled health and power speculation.  His appearance at a meeting in St. Petersburg eased concerns, though his unexplained absence, coupled with a premature media report of the meeting, fueled rumors of illness or a coup.  The Kremlin denied any issues.

Jupiter's migration toward the sun, then outward, likely destroyed earlier "super-Earths" and cleared the inner solar system, creating conditions for the formation of Earth and the other inner, smaller planets.  This explains our solar system's unique structure compared to others.

Two Illinois cousins, one an Army National Guard member, were arrested for plotting to support ISIS.  One planned to join ISIS in Egypt, the other to attack a US military base.  This is part of a larger trend of Westerners joining or supporting ISIS.

Jeremy Clarkson, a Top Gear host, was suspended by the BBC after a controversial Argentina trip where his car's license plate sparked anger, and following a history of racist and offensive remarks.  His actions, including allegedly assaulting a producer, led to widespread condemnation.

Two Steve Jobs biographies offer contrasting portraits.  Isaacson's depicts a cruel genius, while Schlender and Tetzeli's presents a kinder, later-life Jobs, a view endorsed by Apple executives despite being unauthorized.  The new book includes anecdotes about Jobs' final days and a near-missed Stanford speech.

Taraji P. Henson apologized for falsely accusing Glendale police of racially profiling her son during a traffic stop.  Dashcam footage contradicted her son's claims, revealing he possessed marijuana and other contraband.  Henson retracted her statements and thanked the officer for his kindness.

CNN answered viewer questions about Germanwings Flight 9525, addressing the descent rate, lack of crash prevention technology, absence of live cameras, hacking possibilities, lack of explosion on impact, and pilot drug screening frequency.

Wales, led by Gareth Bale's two goals, defeated Israel 3-0 in Euro 2016 qualifying, topping their group.  Italy and Czech Republic escaped defeats against Bulgaria and Latvia, respectively, while Iceland won 3-0.

Wait A Little horse safaris in South Africa offers unique game reserve tours on horseback, primarily using retrained racehorses.  While potentially dangerous, the experienced guides and well-trained horses provide a thrilling, close-up wildlife viewing experience unlike traditional safari vehicles.

Nigeria's military reclaimed Gwoza, Boko Haram's self-proclaimed caliphate headquarters, just before national elections.  This victory, though celebrated by the government, comes amidst ongoing human rights concerns regarding both Boko Haram's brutality and alleged abuses by Nigerian security forces.

Post-election protests and violence erupted in Rivers state, Nigeria, fueled by allegations of election rigging.  Both leading candidates, Jonathan and Buhari, appealed for calm despite fears of widespread unrest mirroring the deadly 2011 post-election violence.  The election's legitimacy hangs in the balance.

Italy's high court definitively acquitted Amanda Knox and Raffaele Sollecito of Meredith Kercher's murder.  The Kercher family is disappointed and may appeal to the European Court of Human Rights.  Knox and Sollecito may sue Italy for wrongful imprisonment, though their chances vary due to prior statements to investigators.

Cyclone Pam, one of the strongest storms ever recorded, devastated Vanuatu, leaving thousands homeless and causing widespread destruction.  The death toll is rising, and the full extent of the damage, particularly to outer islands, remains unknown.  International aid is arriving, but recovery will take years.

A bipartisan criminal justice reform summit unites unlikely allies—from Koch Industries to progressive activists—driven by shared concerns about mass incarceration's violation of liberty and justice principles.  Despite differing views on other issues,  common ground exists in reforming a costly and ineffective system.

Zayn Malik left One Direction, breaking fans' hearts worldwide.  The remaining four members will continue as a group.  News of his departure caused a massive surge in One Direction's music streams, showcasing the band's immense popularity.

Zayn Malik left One Direction, citing unhappiness and a desire for authenticity.  He apologized to fans but feels his departure is best for him and the band, who will continue as a four-piece.  Malik is reportedly pursuing a solo career.

The first "SPECTRE" trailer shows Bond investigating a cryptic message, leading him to infiltrate the terrorist organization SPECTRE.  The trailer hints at a personal mystery involving his past, featuring familiar faces and a new Aston Martin.  The film releases November 6th.

Putin's recent absence sparked intense online speculation about his health and whereabouts, highlighting Russia's personality-cult political system and raising concerns about a potential power vacuum and the country's future without him.

A Rolling Stone article alleging a gang rape at the University of Virginia was found by Charlottesville police to lack substantive evidence.  The magazine apologized, admitting discrepancies and misplaced trust in the accuser.  An independent review is forthcoming.

Kylie Minogue will perform a 90-minute show at the Dubai World Cup, a horse racing event with $30 million in prize money.  The multi-talented star is excited to perform at this prestigious event,  combining her passion for music with her Australian upbringing's connection to horse racing.

Thousands protested terrorism in Tunis, two weeks after the Bardo Museum attack claimed over 20 lives.  President Essebsi and world leaders joined the "Je suis Bardo" demonstration, following the killing of a key suspect in a raid.  The protest showed Tunisian unity against terrorism.

Richard III's remains, discovered under a Leicester car park, will be reburied next week in a coffin crafted by a distant relative whose DNA helped identify the king.  The reburial includes a procession and ceremonies aiming to rehabilitate his historical image.

Senator Harry Reid's retirement paves the way for Chuck Schumer's likely ascension as Senate Democratic leader.  Despite progressive opposition, Schumer's extensive political experience, fundraising prowess, and broad network position him strongly for success.

Seven college students were critically wounded in a Panama City Beach spring break shooting.  A suspect was arrested on attempted murder charges.  The chaotic scene involved numerous witnesses and multiple law enforcement agencies.  The city council considered, but rejected, a beach alcohol ban.

A Germanwings Airbus A320 crashed in the French Alps, killing all 150 aboard.  The cause is unknown, but one black box has been recovered.  The victims included many German school children.  International efforts are underway for recovery and investigation.

AMC's "The Walking Dead" prequel spin-off, "Fear the Walking Dead," will premiere late summer 2015.  Set in Los Angeles during the zombie outbreak's beginning, it features new characters and storylines, with a second season already confirmed.

Kentucky dominated West Virginia, advancing to the Elite Eight with a 37-0 record.  Notre Dame, Wisconsin, and Arizona also won, setting up Elite Eight matchups: Kentucky vs. Wisconsin, and Arizona vs. Notre Dame.  Celebrity sightings added to the excitement.

Lewis Hamilton secured pole position for the Malaysian Grand Prix, beating Sebastian Vettel and teammate Nico Rosberg in qualifying despite torrential rain.  Rosberg was disappointed with third, while Max Verstappen impressed with sixth place.  Tensions between Hamilton and Rosberg were downplayed.

Facing Houthi rebels' takeover, Yemeni President Hadi secured a coalition airstrike from Sunni Arab nations, led by Saudi Arabia, against the Shiite Houthis, whom Saudi Arabia views as Iranian proxies.  The intervention, supported logistically by the US, has caused civilian casualties, sparking controversy.

A commuter train derailed in Los Angeles after colliding with a car, injuring 21 people, two critically.  The accident, near USC, caused traffic concerns for a nearby soccer game, prompting shuttle bus deployment.

Germanwings Flight 9525 crashed in the Alps, killing all 150 aboard.  The co-pilot, Andreas Lubitz, intentionally crashed the plane during a steady descent while the captain was out of the cockpit.  The passengers likely experienced a terrifying final eight minutes.

Jeremy Clarkson's suspension from "Top Gear" sparked a near-million-signature petition for his reinstatement, delivered via tank.  His future remains uncertain pending an internal BBC investigation, though he's expressed pessimism.  High-profile support includes Prime Minister David Cameron.

Montoursville, Pennsylvania, expresses sympathy to Haltern am See, Germany, after a plane crash mirroring their own 19-year-old tragedy.  They share their experience of community grief, support, and long-term healing, offering assistance to the bereaved.

Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz intentionally crashed a plane, killing all aboard.  This horrific act shattered the public's perception of pilots as infallible, highlighting the inherent human fallibility within even the most highly trained professionals.

The March 30, 2015, CNN Student News covered Nigerian elections, an astronaut as a space station experiment, and a fire-extinguishing sound wave invention.  The segment also included a school roll call feature.

Manchester United's 3-0 victory over Tottenham boosted their Champions League hopes, while Chelsea's draw with Southampton extended their EPL lead.  Real Madrid beat Levante 2-0, with Bale scoring both goals.  Rooney's playful goal celebration was a highlight.

Thousands mourned Singapore's founding father, Lee Kuan Yew, at a state funeral attended by global dignitaries.  His death prompted widespread grief and tributes, celebrating his economic achievements while acknowledging criticisms of his authoritarian rule.

Houthi rebels seized Taiz airport, escalating Yemen's conflict.  The UN warns of imminent civil war as violence increases, including a deadly mosque bombing claimed by ISIS, prompting the US to withdraw personnel.  President Hadi's legitimacy is disputed.

A video surfaced of a fraternity's house mother repeatedly using the n-word while singing along to a song.  Despite the offensive language, two Black alumni defended her, citing her long history of kindness and claiming she wasn't racist.  This occurred amidst a larger scandal involving the fraternity's racist chanting, leading to its closure and student expulsions.

South Carolina Aquarium rescued a rare, 475-pound juvenile leatherback sea turtle, a potentially only the fifth such US rescue.  Found hypoglycemic but improving, it will likely be released back into the ocean soon.

ISIS claimed responsibility for a deadly attack at Tunis' Bardo Museum, killing 23, mostly foreign tourists.  The attack, possibly by local ISIS affiliates, targeted Tunisia's tourism sector and raises concerns about the country's stability despite its democratic progress.

Nuclear talks between Iran and world powers intensified, nearing a Tuesday deadline.  Key disagreements remain on limiting Iranian advanced nuclear research and the pace of sanctions lifting.  While some progress was made,  Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu expressed deep concern.  A framework deal is hoped for by Tuesday, but a final agreement is uncertain.

A jury found Robin Thicke and Pharrell Williams liable for copyright infringement of Marvin Gaye's "Got to Give It Up" with their song "Blurred Lines," awarding the Gaye family over $7 million in damages.  The verdict sets a precedent for music copyright cases.

Over half the world's population now lives in cities, a trend projected to increase.  African cities, particularly in sub-Saharan Africa, are experiencing rapid growth and attracting investment, though North African cities currently hold stronger rankings due to existing infrastructure.  Competition for economic dominance is intensifying.

Trevor Noah will replace Jon Stewart as host of "The Daily Show."  Stewart, who departs after 16 years, approves of Noah, a 31-year-old South African comedian.  The show, known for its satirical news coverage, has launched successful spin-offs and careers.

In Lagos, Nigeria, "free readers" gather at newspaper stands, engaging in lively political and social discussions.  While technically not free, a nominal fee is sometimes charged.  These groups, though declining due to internet access and economic hardship, foster community and even job opportunities.

India's Supreme Court struck down Section 66A of the IT Act, deeming its vague wording on online speech unconstitutional and a violation of free expression.  The ruling follows controversies over arrests for online content and government-mandated content removal.

Three Southern California school owners were arrested for a "pay-to-stay" scheme.  They allegedly defrauded the immigration system by enrolling 1,500 foreign students who never attended classes, collecting $6 million annually in tuition.  The scheme involved four schools offering fraudulent I-20 forms for student visas.

The Duchess of Cambridge made her final public appearance before her April maternity leave, visiting the Stephen Lawrence Centre and a youth charity in London with Prince William.  This is their second child.

The Germanwings Flight 9525 crash highlights the critical role of pilot mental health.  The co-pilot's deliberate actions underscore the need for more rigorous and frequent psychological testing for pilots, despite the inherent unpredictability of human behavior.

Sam Taylor-Johnson will not direct the "Fifty Shades" sequels due to creative differences with author E L James, who will write the screenplay for "Fifty Shades Darker."  Despite the first film's box office success,  a new director will helm the next installments.

Despite a recent shoulder dislocation from a fall, 85-year-old Arnold Palmer plans to hit the ceremonial tee shot at the Masters, joining Jack Nicklaus and Gary Player on April 9th, even without current doctor's permission to swing a club.

Negotiations for a nuclear deal with Iran are nearing a deadline.  While progress has been made, key disagreements remain, particularly regarding sanctions relief and the number of Iranian centrifuges.  Both Iranian and US officials express cautious optimism, but significant hurdles persist.

Millions of Chinese children are left behind by parents migrating to cities for work, suffering from neglect, behavioral problems, and lack of access to education and resources due to the restrictive hukou system.  This creates social and societal issues, prompting calls for reform.

Afghan President Ghani's Washington visit precedes potential Taliban peace talks, but success is unlikely due to the Taliban's strong position, a weak Afghan government, and the risk of splinter groups.  US support, slowing troop withdrawal, and bolstering the Afghan government are crucial for future negotiation success.

Iraqi forces, aided by Shia militias and US airstrikes, have made significant gains in Tikrit, capturing key areas and raising the Iraqi flag.  Despite IED challenges and previous setbacks, this renewed offensive shows progress against ISIS.

Hillary Clinton's email controversy is the latest in a long line of scandals she's weathered.  Her strategy:  attack accusers, wait out the media frenzy, and rally her base.  Her resilience suggests she'll survive this too, but the outcome remains uncertain.

Swedish prosecutors, facing a statute of limitations, will interview Julian Assange in London and take his DNA, a request his lawyer views positively.  Assange, seeking to avoid US extradition, has been in the Ecuadorian embassy since 2012.

New Zealand won a thrilling World Cup semifinal against South Africa, reaching their first-ever final thanks to Grant Elliott's last-ball six.  Rain interrupted the match, but New Zealand chased down the revised target of 298, overcoming a shaky middle period.  They will face either Australia or India in the final.

Young Chinese, seeking solace in a competitive society, are increasingly turning to Buddhism, particularly the Tibetan branch.  While some embrace it deeply, many others integrate its practices selectively, viewing it more as a cultural influence than a strict religion.

A suicide truck bomb attack on an Egyptian security forces camp in Al-Arish, North Sinai, killed a civilian and injured 44 (mostly soldiers).  The driver also died.  No group claimed responsibility, but the attack reflects ongoing insurgency in the region.

Al-Shabaab militants attacked government offices in Baidoa, Somalia, killing nine including four attackers.  A car bomb and gunfire ensued.  Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility, while the AU condemned the attack, viewing it as a desperate act following recent defeats.

Eugenie Bouchard and Justin Bieber played tennis doubles at a charity event.  Bouchard tweeted about Bieber's "nice serve," fulfilling a past playful wish for a date with him.  Caroline Wozniacki also interacted with Bieber at the event.

Iran nuclear negotiations progress despite Israeli opposition.  While Israel possesses the military capability to strike Iranian facilities,  doing so post-agreement would have severe geopolitical consequences, making a military option implausible.  Israel's response will likely focus on diplomatic pressure.

Kenya is a major cut-flower exporter, particularly roses, benefiting from its climate and transport links.  The industry employs hundreds of thousands, though environmental concerns exist.  While Europe is the main market, Kenya is diversifying globally and assisting Rwanda's flower sector development.

Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson hosted *Saturday Night Live*,  memorably portraying Bambi and "The Rock Obama."  He then surprised Wrestlemania 31 fans with a  team-up with Ronda Rousey against WWE executives.
The Vatican hosted 150 homeless people on a special tour, including the Vatican Museums and Sistine Chapel, organized by the Office of Papal Charities to showcase the Vatican's artistic heritage.

The UK Supreme Court ruled to release Prince Charles' private letters to government officials, ending a decade-long legal battle.  The Guardian fought for their release, arguing the letters show potential political meddling, while the government and Prince Charles cited privacy concerns.

The author revisits Kipling's "Jungle Book," reflecting on human-tiger conflict in India.  While poaching is a threat, human encroachment and retaliatory killings pose a greater danger.  Despite a recent increase in tiger numbers, the growing human population presents a significant challenge to their survival.

Indiana's Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA) sparked backlash due to fears of LGBT discrimination.  While the governor initially defended the law,  legislative pressure led to calls for a "fix," likely involving either a statewide anti-discrimination law (unlikely) or an amendment preserving local ordinances (more probable, but potentially gutting the RFRA's intent).  The controversy highlights the law's potential for enabling discrimination against the LGBT community.

Jordan Spieth won the Valspar Championship, becoming only the fourth player since 1940 to win twice on the PGA Tour before 22.  He's now focused on surpassing Rory McIlroy and becoming world No. 1, viewing this victory as a significant step towards that goal.

The April 1, 2015, CNN Student News covered global events (Nigeria, Switzerland, West Africa), U.S. wages impacting the economy, and the potential of cyborg cockroaches for rescue missions.  The show also included a transcript and a student roll call.

Lewis Hamilton won the season-opening Australian Grand Prix, leading a Mercedes 1-2 finish.  Sebastian Vettel took third for Ferrari.  Several drivers retired, highlighting Mercedes' dominance and a disappointing race for other teams.  Hamilton playfully interacted with Arnold Schwarzenegger on the podium.

Michael Douglas recounts an anti-Semitic attack on his son, Dylan, prompting him to advocate against rising anti-Semitism.  He attributes this rise to various factors and calls for collective action to combat it, emphasizing the need to confront such incidents directly.

Researchers recreated a 1000-year-old Anglo-Saxon eye salve recipe, finding it highly effective against MRSA, a drug-resistant superbug.  The salve's potent antibiotic properties, exceeding those of some conventional treatments, surprised scientists and challenge perceptions of medieval medicine.

Netanyahu's pre-election denial of a Palestinian state, though retracted, damaged US-Israel and Israeli-Palestinian relations.  Palestinians distrust Netanyahu, may seek UN recognition, and the US will reassess its relationship with Israel, jeopardizing future peace talks.

Indiana's new religious freedom law, allowing businesses to refuse service based on religious beliefs, sparked a social media firestorm.  Supporters cite religious freedom, while opponents call it discriminatory.  A boycott is underway, but some Indiana businesses reject discrimination.

London's Fourth Plinth features Hans Haacke's "Gift Horse," a skeletal bronze horse with a stock ticker, commenting on power, money, and history.  Reactions are mixed, with some finding it confusing and others appreciating its wit and artistic merit.
Adam West and Burt Ward hinted at voicing Batman and Robin in a new 90-minute animated film celebrating the 1960s TV series' 50th anniversary in 2016.  Warner Bros. hasn't confirmed the project.

Negotiations on a framework agreement for Iran's nuclear program were extended to Wednesday.  While progress was made, disagreements remain on sanctions relief, Iran's nuclear advancements, and the handling of its fissile material.  A final deal is still uncertain.

BBC Director-General Tony Hall received death threats after firing "Top Gear" host Jeremy Clarkson following a producer assault.  Police are investigating the email threat, originating outside the UK.  The firing sparked a million-signature petition for Clarkson's reinstatement.

Julianne Moore's Oscar win for "Still Alice" highlights the urgent need to address Alzheimer's, disproportionately affecting women.  The author, launching the "Wipe Out Alzheimer's" campaign, calls for increased research funding and public awareness to combat this growing epidemic.
A Canadian tourist, Jennifer Karren, died after a whale collision with a small inflatable tour boat off Cabo San Lucas.  Two others were injured.  The incident is under investigation.

Ivory Coast's Simone Gbagbo received a 20-year prison sentence for crimes against humanity stemming from the 2010 post-election violence.  Her husband, Laurent Gbagbo, awaits trial at the ICC for similar charges.  Both deny the accusations.

Rory McIlroy, after throwing his 3-iron into a lake, had it retrieved by Donald Trump.  Trump returned the club, but McIlroy promptly hit another shot into the water.  Despite this, Dustin Johnson won the tournament, making a triumphant return after a break.

Wichita, Kansas, high school students surprise principal with kind-hearted senior prank .

Jeff Goldblum set to reprise his role in "Independence Day 2"
Liam Hemsworth and Jessie Usher also cast in key roles .
Sequel will be released 20 years after the original box office smash about an alien invasion .

Walter Mondale was released from the Mayo Clinic on Saturday, hospital spokeswoman said .
The former vice president, 87, was treated for cold and flu symptoms .

A man in suburban Boston is selling snow online to customers in warmer states .
For $89, he will ship 6 pounds of snow in an insulated Styrofoam box .

Jina Krause-Vilmar: On International Women's Day, focus on helping refugee women adapt to new lives .
She says aid agencies like hers aim to help these women build job skills and financial literacy .
She says the effort includes educating men about wives' and daughters' new roles .

Real Madrid slump to defeat against Athletic Bilbao .
Solitary goal from Aritz Aduriz enough to give the Basques victory .
Bayern Munich continue Bundesliga domination .

Police in Japan say they have arrested a man, 40, after five neighbors were fatally stabbed .
The accused shares the same surname as the victims, aged 59 to 84, local media say .
A police official says the man has admitted to the stabbings but refused to comment further .
Car bomb detonated near police vehicle in Lashkar Gah, deputy governor says .

The terror attacks in India left more than 160 people dead .
A  court granted the suspect bail last year .

Police: Officer fired two shots when the man charged at him .
The case was immediately turned over to the GBI .

A photo of a green woodpecker flying with a weasel on its back has gone viral on Twitter .
The image was snapped by amateur photographer Martin Le-May near London .
It sparked the hashtag #weaselpecker and has spawned numerous memes .

A wag decided to sell "air from Kanye West concert" on eBay .
Bidding got to more than $60,000 before plug was pulled .
Others are now doing similar auctions .

Delta Air Lines Flight 1086 skidded into a fence last week at a LaGuardia Airport beset by winter weather .
The NTSB says the crew reported they did not sense any deceleration from the wheel brake upon landing .

More than 100 schools renamed in honor of students killed in a Taliban schoolhouse attack .
A six-hour siege at a Peshawar school killed 145 people in December .

#thedress was an Internet sensation: Is it blue and black or white and gold?
The Salvation Army in South Africa is using it to raise awareness .
The reaction has been mostly positive .

The lack of charges against Busch expedited the decision, a NASCAR official says .
Kurt Busch was accused of grabbing his ex-girlfriend by the throat, slamming her head .
He twice appealed NASCAR's indefinite suspension and lost .

Interim report exposes delays and inaction after MH370 disappeared .
Flight carrying 239 people and crew has not been found, one year later .
Took 10 hours for the first search flights to take off, according to report .

167 people have been rescued, Myanmar's government says .
The ferry capsized after being hit by a large wave in bad weather conditions .

China sends fighter jets to patrol over border with Myanmar following the incident .
Report: In addition to the fatalities, nine others were wounded .

According to a Pew report, 80% of Internet users have looked up health info online .
Sites like Mayo Clinic and others curated by doctors are safer than online forums .

Erich Nowsch will face three charges, including first-degree murder .
He is accused of killing Tammy Meyers in front of her home .
The two lived withing walking distance of each other .

Latest Ferguson shootings push strained race relations to breaking point .
Donna Brazile: Relationship between police forces and minority communities must improve .

North Korea apologizes to Bangladesh after one of embassy's diplomat caught with 59 pounds of gold .
Gold was undeclared, says Bangladeshi government .

Baby Lily was trapped in the car in the cold river for as long as 14 hours .
"She knows everything she knew before anything happened. It's amazing," father says .
Lily's mother, Lynn Jennifer Groesbeck, died in the crash .

The chopper was registered to an air ambulance company .
It was en route from Tulsa to McAlester .

A Californian startup has developed a circular smartphone called "Runcible"
The provocative anti-phone is meant to be an antidote to our obsession for digital devices .

Official "Star Wars" universe gets its first gay character, a lesbian governor .
The character appears in the upcoming novel "Lords of the Sith"
Characters in "Star Wars" movies have gradually become more diverse .

The Pakistani Taliban claims responsibility for the suicide bombings .
At least 78 people were wounded in the attack, hospital official says .

IRS scam has swindled victims out of more than $15 million since 2013 .
